bibl.title: Letter from Harry J. Warthen to Philip Showalter Hench, January 11, 1952

div1.p: Warthen informs Hench that the Richmond Academy of Medicine will not be able to provide financial aid for the preservation of Building No. 1. He also regrets that it will not be possible to exhibit any of the Reed items at the annual history section meeting, but appreciates Hench's offer to lend copies of some of the originals and states which items he would like.

div1.head: Letter from Harry J. Warthen to Philip Showalter Hench, January 11, 1952
div1.opener:
RICHMOND ACADEMY OF MEDICINE
1200 EAST CLAY STREET
RICHMOND 19, VIRGINIA
January 11, 1952
Dr. Philip Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you for your detailed letter of November 20 with
enclosed reprints, which was written in reply to my querry
concerning the possible loan of Walter Reed items on the
occasion of our annual meeting of The Section of the History
of Medicine to be held on February 12. I have been delayed
in replying pending a meeting of The Section Board to discuss
the points raised in your letter.

First, in reply to the last question in your letter
(the possibility of the Section aiding in the raising of funds
for the preservation of the little building in Cuba) would
state that while we are in complete sympathy with the efforts
you have made to save this building we do not feel our limited
resources will permit us to aid financially at this time. Our
annual dues which must cover all phases of The Section's activi-
ties total approximately two hundred dollars. The Board ex-
pressed the hope that on one of your trips to the East you may
find it possible to visit Richmond and give us an opportunity
to meet and also have you tell us more about your plans in
Cuba.

I am sorry that conditions preclude exhibiting any of
the items you have associated with the life of Walter Reed,
but we appreciate your willingness to lend us copies of some
of the originals.

If you would find it possible to give us photostats of
the originals, listed as items 1 to 11 inclusive in your
letter, we would be very glad to defray the cost of having
these made. Item # 3 could be omitted for we already have
photographs of Reed's birthplace which some of our members
played a prominent role in preserving.

Thanking you for your interest in this matter, and
with kind personal regards, I remain

closer.signed:
Harry J. Warthen, Jr., M. D.
Chairman, Section on the
History of Medicine
